Comment: I quickly skimmed. I didn't think the article was anti Trump...remember, the administration has only been in power 3 months. You really can't expect big cuts to happen that quickly.    Anyway, this is what it said.   Social Security, medicare, medicaid, and high interest on debt is up. That's to be expected. Our people are older and are collecting more benefits. And we're paying more interest on more debt. Trump hasn't touched those things yet. It's just the natural progression of things.   It does show what Trump has done to decrease spending has been a success: DOE expenses are down, so is TSA and USAID.   The article also explains that while DOGE has done somethings - namely all the fed gov worker cuts - we haven't seen the effects of that yet since they're still on payroll, severance payouts etc.   I thought it was a fair assessment. But again, too early perhaps.
Author: findunk

Comment: If anyone hasn't noticed, when the government does a Continuing Budget Resolution, they end up spending MORE than they would have if a proper budget had been passed.  It is high time we stopped letting them scare us with the Social Security and other boogeymen that are patently false.  Back during Trump's first term the Government was shutdown for 35 days. Socials Security payments were NOT interrupted, .  During the 2018-2019 government shutdown, paychecks were interrupted for some military personnel. Specifically, about 41,000 active-duty Coast Guard members, 6,000 reservists, and 8,500 civilian employees did not receive their paychecks because the Coast Guard falls under the Department of Homeland Security, not the Defense Department.  During the 2013 shutdown, Congress passed legislation that allowed uniformed personnel to receive their paychecks during the shutdown, but this statute was limited to "members of the Armed Forces," excluding USPHS and NOAA Corps officers.
